entries.text: Sawyer's weekly update from the P5P mailing list. One of the changes coming in Perl 5.26 is not including '.' in @INC, the implications of which are still rumbling on.

entries.author: steve_bertrand
entries.text: Berrybrew is a tool for Windows users that can manage installations of multiple versions of Perl, like perlbrew. There's a new version of berrybrew available, and this post summarises the changes.
entries.title: berrybrew, the Perlbrew for Windows has been updated

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: The Perl Toolchain Summit is only possible with support from sponsors. To acknowledge our Platinum and Gold sponsors, we'll be doing a series of blog posts about toolchain topics, each thanking one sponsor. This first post, an introduction to distribution metadata files, is brought to you by FastMail.
entries.title: An introduction to CPAN distribution metadata

entries.author: graham_ollis
entries.text: An Alien distribution is one that relies on a third party library, typically written in C or similar. Here Graham introduces alienfile, a new recipe system for installing the external packages that an Alien distribution depends on.
entries.title: alienfile

entries.author: caleb_cushing
entries.text: For some very pragmatic and understandable reasons, Caleb made the transition from Perl to Java, and here he shares some of his thoughts on that.

entries.text: For March, the CV Library team was assigned Linux::Unshare in the CPAN Pull Request Challenge. Here Lance describes their evening spent scoffing pizza and working on the dist's one open bug in RT.

entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: I was so happy with the CV Library team's efforts (team bonding that improves CPAN for all of us!) that I wrote this post to try and encourage more dev groups to join the pull request challenge as a team.

header:
The development group at CV Library have joined the Pull Request Challenge as a team.
This month Lance describes how they got together over pizza to learn about XS distributions
and fix a gnarly outstanding bug. Already another group has asked to sign up,
so if you're part of a Perl dev group, maybe you could sign up your team too?
subject: Teams and the Pull Request Challenge
